2. Prohibits any person from knowingly selling or disposing of a gun to these individuals.

3. Authorizes $25 million in additional funding for the next 5 years for states to report pretrial orders involving gun restrictions to the national background check system. 

9/

The #PreventingPretrialGunPurchases Act does 3 basic things: 

1. Amends federal gun laws to deny gun sales to any person subject to a pretrial release order from a court that prohibits the person from purchasing, possessing, or receiving guns.

8/

Today, I'm releasing the #PreventingPretrialGunPurchases Act with 25 original cosponsors and 41 endorsing organizations to honor the victims of gun violence by strengthening our background check system. #HonorWithAction #EndGunViolence 7/ https://t.co/uXW0ACMufB

I got to work and reached out to orgs & advocates like @GiffordsCourage, @bradybuzz, @NewtownAction, @VPCinfo, @Everytown @CJACTIONFUND, @sandyhook, @GAGnoguns, @fred_guttenberg, and more to write a new law to prevent those LEGALLY ORDERED NOT TO HAVE guns from getting them.  6/

And although this started with January 6 in mind, I quickly realized how this could apply to dangerous individuals accused of crimes like murder, sexual assault, and domestic violence. 

Imagine a domestic abuser being able to buy a gun after a judge prohibits it.  5/

In short, a judge could order you not to have guns, but that wouldn't necessarily show up on a background check.

Instead of being proactive in keeping guns away from dangerous individuals, the current law is reactive.  4/

Federal law requires gun sellers to conduct a background check before completing a gun sale but doesn't prohibit the sale of guns to people who are prohibited from purchasing guns as a condition of a pretrial release court order.  3/

The thought of an insurrectionist amassing this kind of arsenal was troubling, to say the least. So I asked my staff to look into it and see if there were any laws on the books that weren't being enforced or proposals we could sign onto to address this.

We couldn't find any.  2/

‚Åì 11:30 AM: I return to the Capitol. As construction crews and the brave members of the Capitol Police and National Guard secure the Capitol Complex, we begin our work to protect our democracy. https://t.co/sMxpmnNKrO

‚Åì3:30 AM: I take one last look at the Capitol before leaving with my staff. Our democracy, like the building, is deeply damaged but still standing. It is clear that January 6 will not mark the end of the attacks on our democracy. https://t.co/OUlywpVI7B

3:24 AM: After all the objections are rejected, Congress completes the counting of the electoral votes, with Biden winning, 306‚Äì232; Vice President Pence affirms the election result, formally declaring Biden the winner.
3:10 AM: The House rejects, 282‚Äì138, the Republican objection against the counting of Pennsylvania's electoral votes.
12:55 AM: The Senate rejects, 92‚Äì7, the objection raised by a handful of Republican senators against the counting of Pennsylvania's electoral votes.
12:15 AM: Republican Rep Scott Perry and Senator Josh Hawley object to the counting of Pennsylvania's electoral votes, triggering a two-hour debate in both chambers.

11:30 PM: The House votes 303‚Äì121 to reject the objection to Arizona's electoral votes. Whatever hope there was that Rs would let go of the Big Lie in the wake of the mayhem it caused was dashed as a majority of the House GOP gave in to the insurrectionists‚Äô demands.

11:00 PM: I head down to the House Chamber for the first time that day to vote on the objection to Arizona‚Äôs electoral vote. Dedicated congressional staff are already at work repairing the damage caused that day.
10:15 PM: The Senate votes 93‚Äì6 against the objection raised by a handful of Republican senators against the counting of Arizona's electoral votes.
9:00 PM: Speaker Pelosi reopens the House debate. We were determined to finish the job we had come to do and we were not going to leave until it was done.

‚Åì 8:15 PM: I leave the office for the first time in 10 hours and head to the Capitol building where there is food waiting for us. There is destruction all around the building. I return back to my office with a pizza for staff. https://t.co/dW8cbhw52T
8:00 PM: U.S. Capitol Police declare the Capitol building to be secure.
‚Åì 7:00 PM: Facebook and Twitter remove President Trump's posts.
6:01 PM: President Trump again tweets his Big Lie claims and does not denounce the rioters who came in his name.

6:00 PM: D.C. curfew comes into effect. It seems that the Capitol has been mostly cleared by this point. I begin taking calls from the press to update my constituents on what is happening. It helps to keep busy as we try to process what just happened. https://t.co/o2EVGN2zFW

‚Åì 5:45 PM: We learn of a staffer next door from my office who has been all alone throughout the insurrection as his boss had been on the floor. We quickly rush him into our office for some added peace of mind.
5:20 PM: Within 12 minutes of receiving permission, the DC National Guard arrives at the Capitol roughly 4 hours after being requested and more than 3 hours after being prepared to deploy.
5:08 PM: DC National Guard receives the Secretary of Defense's permission to deploy to the Capitol.
4:32 PM: Defense Secretary Miller finally authorizes DC National Guard to actually deploy in support of Capitol Police.
4:17 p.m.: Trump uploads a video to his Twitter repeating his Big Lie claims and telling the rioters, ‚Äúwe love you.‚Äù

4:08 PM: Vice President Pence speaks with Acting Secretary of Defense Miller and directs him to ‚Äúclear the Capitol.‚Äù 

Something President Trump should have done from the safety of the White House hours earlier.

4:05 PM: President-elect Biden holds a press conference calling on President Trump to "demand an end to this siege".
https://t.co/YIS5o4MzGz

3:04 PM: Secretary Miller, formally approves "activation" of the DC National Guard. This is not permission to deploy, just to call up National Guard forces to head to the Armory.

This would have been a good time to deploy the National Guard.
2:44 PM: Rioter Ashli Babbitt is shot by Capitol Police while attempting to forcibly enter the Speaker's Lobby as members are being evacuated from the House floor.

2:30 PM: Secretary Miller, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Mark Milley, and Army Secretary McCarthy meet to discuss Capitol Police and D.C. government requests.

This would have been a good time to deploy the National Guard.

‚Åì2:25 p.m.: Army Secretary McCarthy ordered staff to prepare movement of the emergency reaction force, but to remain at the Armory until he confirmed approval from Acting [Defense Secretary Miller].‚Äù 

This would have been a good time to deploy the National Guard.

2:24 PM: Trump tweets an attack against his own Vice President who is being hunted by a mob chanting to hang Mike Pence. It is safe to assume that Trump was looking at the same images as the rest of us and had an idea of the danger the VP was in.

2:20 PM: The House is gaveled into recess and begins to evacuate. I will never forget the sight of Speaker Pelosi being whisked away by her security detail.
https://t.co/sjr0ToRqvW

2:19 PM: DC officials advise the DC National Guard that ‚ÄúU.S. Capitol building windows are being broken‚Äù and request that D.C. National Guard members ‚Äúreport to the U.S. Capitol immediately.‚Äù 

This would have been a good time to deploy the National Guard.
